reviewText:
I'm not normally a person who writes reviews for games, but after hearing and seeing some of things others are saying about this game and about how the creator of the game has become discouraged due to particular reviews I felt compelled to share my thoughts on this game.

While it is certainly not a masterpiece or a majorly innovative concept, it has a delightful charm to it. I belive that too many people come into this game expecting it to have the same off-the-walls wacky gameplay that Goat Simulator brought to the table and find themselves disapointed when the find out that there aren't any people to bowl over or explosions to create. Bear Simulator instead focuses on is creating a setting where there is a story to be told that the player has to discover by exploring as much as they can and finding food and clues as to what's going on. Everything is not as ordinary as it seems as the player progresses, and the fun is in slowly discovering new things, which admittedly is not for everyone.

A notable discovery early on is the fact that you are not a full grown bear, but rather a cub. In one of the very first areas that you will explore there will be a sign stating that a cub and not any full grown bears reside in the area. If you stop to think about it some more you'll realize that all the other animals you encounter are rather large comparative to you. And this brings me to anoter common misconception about the game. Many people who have played this game find it unfathomable that you, as a bear, are not smart enough to eat certain foods or are getting killed by a fox. While a normal adult bear would have no trouble with these things, you are just a stupid and frail cub and will need to eat everything in sight to grown stronger and smarter.

To end this I would just like to give a simple message to the developer of this game. Don't give up, man. A lot have people have found the actual method to enjoying your game. It's completely normal to make mistakes at the beginning which will net a lot of criticism on you. If you feel you need to take a break then go ahead, but please don't say you'll shelve your talent away forever. You've managed to achieve something here that plenty of other people can only dream about being able to do by getting your own game published and put up for sale on steam. I am one of those people. I don't know if you'll even get this message, but if you do, then whatever you decide to do in the end, then just make sure you're happy with your decision.

You need 15 intelligence to eat a hamburger in this game. That about sums it up.

Poor animation, poor sound, poor bear simulation. The world feels incredibly empty as you walk aimlessly through nondescript valleys with little signs of life. It's hard to keep track of where you've been, especially since there's no map. Every now and then you'll come across an oversized animal or bug, but they are few and far between, and will either attack you or flee. Beyond that you eat food such as berries, bugs, junk food and fish which will give you stat points.

The developer could have focused a bit more on adding animation and sound to you as the bear, and the environment. There could have been birds flying in the air, schools of fish in the river, and tiny bugs crawling around. Instead this is an entirely too dull and uninspired experience which I only dragged myself through after having backed it on Kickstarter maybe just a bit too optimistically.

reviewText:
In 1979 I was serving as a park ranger in the northwestern quadrant of Yellowstone Park. My partner Steve was sick with typhoid fever, and I was serving my shifts alone. I got a call in the morning that some campers (who were camping ILLEGALLY) had spotted a grizzly bear within 100 feet of their campground. As a devoted ranger, it was my RESPONSIBILITY to protect these people. When I responded to the call, I came upon a campground painted with the blood and guts of these park visitors. I almost VOMITED in pure disgust. Little did I know, the grizzly bear that had committed this atrocious act of violence was still lurking amidst the trees only meters away from where I stood. He must have smelled the peanut butter sandwich I held in my pants pocket. He charged at me, tackling me to the ground with a level of force unrivaled by any earthly creature. Luckily, I had a .44 in my ankle holster, which I used to shoot the bear in the neck, as he snacked on my delicious sandwich (later I learned this bear was allergic to peanut butter anyway). Did I flinch or hesitate to destroy this animal? No, because I had to do it to save my own skin. If I had a scud missile I would've used it. Maybe it was perverse of me to open this game, expecting to play this kind-of encounter out from the other side, but regardless, I didn't get to experience any scenario close to the TERROR of my own. Although later I learned that bear was a golden retriever. I lost my job that day, but I could've lost my life. Instead, all I got were childish memes, clearly picked from the mind of a CHILD, not seasoned by the horrors and sights of what MEN like myself have seen within national parks. You grass men seem to think creatures like these are JOKES. They aren't. A bear killed my brother in '92.

The American Grizzly Bear is one of the most formidable animals in any given forest. Its power is unmatched. One strike from its muscular limbs could leave a man dead.

If you're giving a game in which I step into the body of a BEAR, THEN I'D EXPECT TO FEEL STRONG. I'd EXPECT to overpower any fellow animal, much like that giant golden retriever overpowered me. Nature is NOT a joke. People lose their lives. It's not a little virtual playground for grassmen to make jokes about frogs. Liliputian homunculi.

So next time you think about make a game with bears, please depict them with some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ accuracy. LIfe isn't a meme. Men lose their lives. Golden retrievers (unfortunately) get shot in the throat.

I give this game a 7/10 (I have to admit the frogs were quite humorous).

- Ranger Charles

reviewText:
As a Kickstarter backer of this game, Bear Simulator is an absolute treat that I have played hours on end. As expected, you play as a bear doing bear things like hunting, scavenging, exploring, wearing silly hats, and discovering ancient bear temples. Bear Simulator is a sort of Sandbox/Action & Adventure game with a hint of plot behind it. It should be noted that Bear Simulator is not just a game you can relatively finish and find everything within an hour. In fact, I've played over 18 hours of this game and I still have not seen everything. Most of the fun from Bear Simulator comes from finding and collecting things and exploring the land. So if you enjoy games that center around collecting and adventure, this is the game for you.

With all of that said there are some problems with the game any potential buyer should know about. There are a lot (and I mean A LOT) of places you can get literally stuck in with saving and respawning at your den or whatnot being your only saving grace. Also, the hitboxes for some of the animals can be quite wonky and there are a few platforming segments that can be absolutely rage inducing. However, it should be noted that the single creator of this game, Farjay, is trying to fix these problems but is having a hard time with some of them as he is a first-time game developer.

In the end I feel as if maybe this game should have been released as early access or backer only until more problems were fixed but as it is its a very fun and unique game to play that I would recomend to anyone who enjoys being the best bear they can be and doesn't mind the bugs.

I have enjoyed every second of this game. It gives you exactly everything that you'd ask for in a BEAR simulator. You're a bear, so have fun. The game itself is very soothing to me--akin to something of Viscera clean-up but in a collect-a-thon way. It's not the prettiest game, but that isn't the focus. It's being a bear, and doing bear things.

This game is a wonderful experience, and although it might not be for everyone with its quirky humor and playful gameplay, I've had a blast playing it, and it was worth every cent.

On another note, supposively due to the bad reviews(although few, currently It's at 30 negative to 120+ positive) has incited the game dev to stop developing the game. I hope he continues to make it, there is a lot of promise here, and I really want to see this game at its fully-fledged beartential. Having said that, the game is still well-worth the price.

And Game dev, if you see this, thank you so much for making this game! I love it so much, and you shouldn't let the opinions of the few outweigh the many! reviewText:
Do you want to be a bear? Do you want to wander around exploring, hunting, fishing, scavenging, eating, and climbing around on things? Do you want to sniff around and find out where other animals have been, and what they've been up to? Do you want to uncover spooky ancient mysteries? Well this is the bear game for you!

I've played this now for quite a few hours, plus some more time with the kickstarter preview, and I have to say this is everything I'd hoped it would be. The graphics are better than I expected and quite good for a one-man development team. Few games live up to the hype, but Bear Simulator absolutely delivered. Beware of negative reviews with very little playtime. Those people have surely not even discovered a fraction of what this game has to offer.

Based on my rate of progress, I'd expect this game will take me at least 40 hours to just explore and find everything, eat everything, and complete the game. Not a bad entertainment/price ratio at $15. Anyone who says it'll take less than that has clearly not found any of the hidden zones yet and isn't playing this game to its fullest. There's a lot of secret stuff to discover, and the world is a bigger place than it first appears.

Are there bugs? Sure. Nothing game-breaking though. The game is difficult at times but I've caught, killed, and eaten ducks, successfully fought and killed some other predators, and gotten over or around various barriers that seemed too challenging at first. Sometimes you just need better bear stats before you attempt things, or need to get better at the game. Take your time, really investigate your environment fully, and then only move on when you're absolutely sure you've finished an area. Chances are high you'll still need to come back though, and don't forget that there's different challenges at night, and the weather changes things too.

This game is not for everyone. If you've got no sense of humor, no sense of direction, no attention span, or are obsessed with graphics above all else, you'll probably hate this game. If you like adventure, like exploring every nook-and-cranny of a huge and fascinating world, and don't take things too seriously, you'll have a blast. The game does start slow, and at first doesn't appear very deep. Give it some time, explore a bit, both in daytime and nighttime, and you'll really discover all that this game has to offer. This is not a game that can be judged in a 15 minute let's play.

reviewText:
Just got I think as far as I could into the game, and I enjoyed every minute of it, MOSTLY, nearly completeing everything at 100%. Of course, it took its fair amount of patience, but I rarely lack in that field. That, AND, I'm a huge fan of exploration games, and that's mainly what this game is+adventure+some platforming, rather than a simulator.

You explore to find out what the goal of the game is and its story. To find out why you're playing as a bear. To find out the indications of what you need to do. To find out why you lack stats to eat certain foods or do certain things, even if it doesn't really make sense. And, if you give the game the chance to, it's really made well enough that you get your answers if you bother going beyond what you're maybe usually use to go in video games. Bear Simulator DARES not take you by the hand and show you the way, and instead, pushes you to get out of your comfort zone.

You're not given a map. So what? The game's environnement is designed well enough that you can make your own map in your head without getting confused. There's a whole bunch of beacons and landmarks everywhere, and nothing looks exactly the same. After playing about 10 hours, I knew my way around the entire game world pretty darn easily and if you can run it on high graphics, some of the environnements are pretty darn neat-looking, especially one region of the game, even WITH some low-res and stretched textures.

The game has also a good share of surprises and things that are, depending on how easily you can be amused, pretty worth working hard to unlock, especially after grinding your stats and unlocking new abilities.

Now, for the less positive. Yes, indeed, the game has its BIG share of bugs. Like, I got stuck in some parts of the environnement many MANY times and had to go back to the main menu to reload AND the hit detection is sometimes very ackward, even if you can get it working right after a while.

Yes, the game is rather unfinished, but if you can get pass those two aspects, which I think are the two major ones, to me, really, this was pretty darn worth the money I spent on it, and I would love to see it get properly finished with ALL the other remaining mysteries still left unanswered after completing the last possible objective.

So, overall. Yeah. It ain't a game for everybody to enjoy and you gotta like the gendra and be able to forgive silly things and some bugs here and there to be able to fully have fun playing it. And this, I got all that was needed to achieve.

I kickstarted this game for $30 and I don’t regret it.  It’s exactly what I expected.  A silly, fun, little bear game.  You walk around, beat up animals to eat, and harvest bugs, berries and mushrooms.

Dev doesn’t communicate?  He posted 46 different updates to kickstarter.  He did fine.  The game runs exceptionally well on ultimate graphics settings for me.  I’ve gotten stuck on the map twice, but saving and loading shifts your position, so no big deal.

Yes, you can lose to a fox.  The point of gathering berries, bugs and eating other animals is to improve your stats, such as damage and health.  It’s called progression.  Something too tough?  Gather more things first.  Not sure why everyone is making such a big deal out of such a simple game.

The game is incredibly in depth for a one man project, especially his first project.  Don’t listen to the kickstarter hype.  I’m satisfied with my backing.  Honestly I’d say this is almost fit to be a children’s game.  If you’re looking for a serious game, then move on.  This is just a little silly fun.

To get this game via Kickstarter was only $15.  Same price as it is now.

There were 17 different updates emailed out by Kickstarter to backers in 2015 alone between March and September. 45 updates since backing.  The Dev wasn't silent.

It had an  estimated  release of Nov. 2014.  Pretty good for a one man show's first time.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this. I backed it on Kickstarter and I don't regret that for a moment. It's a silly little collect-a-thon that reminds me of shareware games from yonks ago, along with a little bit of Twilight Princess's wolf Link, and a dash of walking simulator thrown in. It's a laugh being a bear. And honestly, some of it's pretty clever and I'd love to see the idea developed even further. It has some real potential behind it!

I've mostly played this in its Kickstarter Humble Bundle preview release version, and recently (finally) got around to switching to the Steam version. So I don't have too many hours here, yet.

I've heard that this has been unfairly roasted by PewDiePie and that that's killed the enthusiasm of the developer. This saddens me. After all the misogynistic, homophobic, racist, and generally unpleasant and imbecilic things that come out of his channel, it's really not clever to put any stock in it. He's discredited himself on countless, countless occasions. And the fans are often rabid and crazy enough to deserve being institutionalised. Not a good crowd.

So, that said, do I recommend this? Do you enjoy game where you've played as an animal or animal-like creature? Such as Okami, Ori, Twilight Princess, and so on? Do you like mysteries and collect-a-thons? Do you, perhaps, have an urge to eat all of the things? And do you enjoy playing games which are just a little bit different?

Then yeah. Be a bear. It's a laugh, and the price is right for it.

reviewText:
This game is very fun to play and I think it's best for people who enjoy exploration/survival games. I personally enjoy them, and I think this game is one of a kind.

I really like PewDiePie, but I think there was some kind of a misunderstanding. I don't think he managed to explore the whole map of this game. At first, exploring the forest might be troubling or considered somewhat boring because almost everything is hidden including other regions, but this game is deep. I could definately tell that they put a lot of effort to this game.

I do have to say the bear's story advances slowly. So..At first, it might be hard to get this game, I guess. It has hidden messages if you play it through and explore different areas. Everything is meticulously planned and designed, even the right timing(or bear level) of when to find an area or a special souvenir, etc.

It might be challenging to control your bear or survive or eat something or find something at first, but it's really fun to make the bear eat a lot of different things and discover new areas and make the bear super strong/intelligent. I really like how they made these different areas. If you explore around enough, you'll find a radioactive zone, beautiful beach and even a spooky area. You can also give your bear a fun makeover, which is enjoyable as well. They have a rastafarian hat, a nice cap, glasses, a moustache, and fun bear furs. I also like the casual humour they put in to this game, because fun remarks would pop up if your bear does something that a human wouldn't normally do. It made me laugh while I played. I think this game is appropriate for all age and gender. Everyone can enjoy this.

But I do hope that the bear control would be easier and maybe have more options for choosing my own key for bear movements? cuz I prefer different keys for jumping or running.

If you start upgrading your bear enough, I think you'd definitely find the true essence of this game and what the developer is trying to say. I mean, it even raises awareness on environmental issues! Like I said, this game is deep. It's definitely worth $15. Love this! Keep up the great work, and hope to see this game expand inside and outside.

This game had a lot of potential, but didn't execute it correctly. The color scheme and concept are amazing but everything else doesn't meet that and it's charm of exploring and eating things is removed when you have to scrutinize every detail from the area just so you can make any semblance of progress. I only have 4 hours because I thought it was going to go somewhere at a decent pace. The reason this game is bad isn't because it's inherently a bad game, It had a lot of good things going for it, but the poor execution completely killed this game that, otherwise, would have been very delightful and charming to play.

reviewText:
The way I see it, the game has a lot of potential and there are some well done things in the game, but they are left in the shadows of the negative things in this game. Unfortunely. So, let's get to the review:
(Short version is BEFORE THE summary at the bottom.)

LONG VERSION:


TEH GRAPHFICS

They are good for a Unity game, considering it's just one guy (I assume) who made these all by himself (I assume), I really mean it. I've seen worse. Much worse. Not much to talk about here. Apart from random stuttering and lag in some locations where a lot of stuff is going on, even off-screen. Something Unity is good at in the hands of unexperienced/unseasoned user of Unity. Obviously we've all seen worse optimization, even in AAA games.


TEH AUDIO

Well, we get all the sound effects you might expect: punch, hit, monster idle sounds, etc. There is no ambient music though, so just put on some Mambo #5 and you're good to go. However, the music when you find a temple, or an altar, the music is... intriguing... it adds to the atmosphere of this... mysterious story. That's pretty good. The music in the main menu sounds generic though.


TEH GAMEPLAY

Weeeellll... it's kinda boring. I was hoping for a little more (like everybody else I guess), like you know: you can get a clan of bears, upgrade your cave to hold more bears, go out with your bear-clan and kick some bottoms, fight other bear-clans far away, etc, etc.
Unfortunely, nothing like that here. It would be ok, IF the monsters you fight against would respawn, so it wouldn't be so empty when you kill everything. Yes, the monsters die forever, just like the food you ate disappers forever, so if you're suddenly low on stamina/health and you've killed/ate everything... too bad.
BUT, this killing/eating is tied to progression of you bear. You kill/eat something, your attributes get upgraded. This is where it got in the wrong direction. It would be a smarter decision to make the Bear Points your experience and you can spend Bear Points to upgrade your attributes. That way, you could make stuff respawn, so players could kill them again and get more Bear Points to upgrade other attributes. By making mobs/food add attributes themselves, removes that possibility, because players could just come back to the same mob and kill it over and over to upgrade their jump skill. So the Bear Points have been rendered useless. Unless you care about 2x damage, which doesn't do anything. Still takes about 3 hits to kill a fox. Upgrade strength, then it takes 2. So yeah, Bear Points = useless. They could be experience that you spent on attributes/perks, but unfortunely no.
The combat seems a bit broken. I hit an animal, it immidietly hits me back. Twice. No way to dodge either. Sometimes it works, but sometimes dodging doesn't work even when you're standing behind the monster. It's hard to explain this unless you've played it, but believe me it's terrible. The hit detection is very shoddy too. I point at the monster, right at his heart/head, it misses 50% of the time, whilst they hit you twice per your hit and almost never miss.

When you sleep in the bed, you can choose to sleep until day or night. Apart from changing day to night and night to day, it changes the mobs to different ones. Also, some events/monsters appear/happen only during the night or day, so you'll be doing a lot of back-and-forth from location to location.

HOWEVER... The story, is VERY intriguing. There is something eerie to the story, about... some ancient bears. The story, this... mysteriousness is awesome. It really is. Combined with that strange music when you find the temples is just... a great combination. This is a very strong positive thing to this game. I loved it and that's what kept me playing for... IDK, 12 hours? Of course the combat was annoying and when I killed/ate most of the things it got pretty boring.


TEH CHARACTERS

Well, the models actually look good, especially the bear. The animations are also done well, but the animation for differnet actions, doesn't match up with the speed coded for those actions, so you can see the rabbit moving his legs really fast, but then you look how far he moved and it's just a few centimeters from you. It looked like he would put like a 20 second gap between us, but no.
One of the more annoying non-aggressive mobs has to be THE DUCKS. They take off like a F-16 or something. And like I mention: hit detection is not good, so it's hard to hit them. Also, all the mobs that fight back are annoying too. Why? Read TEH GAMEPLAY.


MISC STUFF

I don't think there's anything else to talk about.  Oh no wait, collectibles. They are there and some of them are useful, others... not so much. Useful: those for the bear, like a bed or a new skin/hat (bear with hats? That's cool). Not-so-useful: the ones for your cave. They don't seem to be doing anything. Except the bed. I also got... a cat that doesn't move or meow, a cat bed, some hats, a different skin and a new bed. I don't know much, because I still haven't finished this game. Surprisingly, this is a very long game, if you want the 100%.
The locations could be unlocked if you had enough Bear Points or level (if Bear Points were actually useful). There is no fast travel as well, so prepare for A LOT of walking, as you go back and forth to explore the same locations during the night and day. It's just... not fun. It's tedious. + when there is no ambient things going on AND when you kill everything there is to kill on your way somewhere, it gets even less fun and more tedious/boring.

SHORT VERSION BELOW.




SHORT VERSION:
The story has a very strong mysterious feel to it and the music that plays when you find temples that are connected to the story adds even more to that atmosphere. A bunch of collectibles like hats and skins and bed upgrades. Also some other collectibles that don't seem to do much, apart from makin your cave prettier/more lively. The combat is not good. The hit detection is shoddy. Character progression has some bad decisions to it, like mobs adding attributes rendering Bear Points (which could be used as experience so players could upgrade stats themselves) useless. Mobs/food doesn't respawn, making your world emptier as you progress. No fast travel. Expect to spend most of your time going back-and-forth to your cave to change from night to day or day to night, as some things happen at night or day.




SUMMARY:
I still recomend this game. It has lots of negatives, some positives, but I don't think those negatives are beacuse of the developer being terrible at... coding or something. Some locations actually look interesting and are well made. I think that he just made some bad decision here and there. Considering how this is his first game, it's not surprising that he made a few things wrong (like making Bear Points useless... I know, I can't get over that, but it just bothers me a lot, since they could work as experience points. Missed potential right here.), but hey, if you don't fall... you... won't know how to stand up? IDK, I'm not good at this.
Overall, it was a tedious/boring adventure so far. The only thing that kept me going was the mysterious thing/story in the game. If you can look past all the other things and focus on the story and mysteriousness/exploration you might put some hours into it... like me.
If you can't look past the problems... this is not for you.

Also, I'm not here to give life advice to the developer, beacuse he feels sad the game got so much hate. I feel sorry for him, I really do. But I'm here to review the game, something the developer can use to better his next game, or update the current one. That's it.

reviewText:
I'm trying to understand why people are so upset about this game (the negative reviews, at least). Many of the funders knew that (1) this is a bear simulator (2) this was Farjay's first real game and (3) the game was more than 3x overfunded, which is not a good thing. You couldn't go into this expecting a 100k game made by an indie professional, and if your negative review is negative because it isn't a game you'd normally pay ~$20 for, then you came in expecting the wrong thing. This game is called Bear Simulator, and it is exactly that.

We start off waking up from hibernation (by that I mean the extra year of development the game took, much of which was without any updates - which I am not using to affect this review) in a bear den. You explore the world, which is surprisingly large and detailed, looking for food. There are a lot of random things to find (e.g. boards that have Bear Facts on them, random signs that have been graffitied), and I've enjoyed reading pretty much everything. Farjay's humor was what originally drew me into the game (other than my love for bears), and the game is rife with it. I personally quickly found myself acting like a bear - all I cared about was finding food. Everything is pretty much about eating in this game, which is pretty much realistic for a bear coming out of hibernation. Granted, the game effectively becomes a big ol' collectaphon, but I've enjoyed the constant need to stuff my bear stomach. Food gives you stat bonuses, and these bonuses help you in your exploration (and subsequently adding more interesting foods to your culinary repertoire. It's fun, it's silly, and it's very bear-like.

Unfortunately, the game does suffer from a few issues:
There is no map, which makes the expansive world a bit difficult to explore consistently
There isn’t much food and few animals to kill, which quickly makes the world seems empty. It’s made worse because the food and animals don’t respawn.
Some items don’t really make sense – e.g. some mushrooms require a certain amount of intelligence…which I’m not really sure the reason behind
There are a number of weird clipping issues when it comes to the environment, just random areas where the controls don’t work well, you can’t jump, etc. It seems to be mostly around rock formations and cliff areas.These were my biggest issues with the game. Otherwise, this is really just a bear simulator with some bonus things in it. It isn’t much like Goat simulator, which many people seem to have expected it to be.
